questions.text: On induction of a patient for a cardiac surgery, large doses of opioids were administered. Following muscle relaxation with a non-depolarising muscle relaxant, it was found that the patient could not be ventilated by positive pressure by the senior anaesthetist. What is the most likely cause of the same?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Chest wall rigidity would be the most likely cause for difficulty in ventilation by positive pressure.

  • In cardiac anaesthesia, large doses of opioids (especially fentanyl, sufentanil, remifentanil) are often used for hemodynamic stability during induction.
  • Rapid IV administration of large doses of an opioid(particularly fentanyl and its derivatives as used in cardiac surgery) can lead to generalised skeletal muscle rigidity
  • This can be severe enough to interfere with manual ventilation
  • High doses of potent synthetic opioids stimulate mu-opioid receptors in the central nervous system, especially in the basal ganglia and brainstem.
  • Although generally termed chest wall rigidity, evidence supports the conclusion that most of the resistance to ventilation is due to laryngeal musculature contraction
  • Even non-depolarizing muscle relaxants may not immediately overcome this rigidity unless a deep level of paralysis is achieved.
  • Prophylaxis for the stiff chest syndrome.
    • Priming with a non-depolarizer.
    • Slow, intermittent, small doses of opioids.
    • Use of an inhalational agent
  • Treatment for stiff chest syndrome
    • Neuromuscular blocking agents
    • Naloxone

Explanation of Other Options:

Improper technique(Option A): Not a reliable option

Leak around the mask (Option C): Would typically cause easy but ineffective bagging, not resistance.

Inadequate relaxation (Option D): Partial neuromuscular blockade may cause movement or laryngospasm, but won’t cause a rigid chest unless related to opioids.

questions.text: For an awake craniotomy in a patient with an intracerebral tumour, a wake-up test is planned during the surgery. Which opioid would be the best for analgesia and sedation in such patients?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Remifentanil opioid would be the best for analgesia and sedation for an awake craniotomy

  • During awake craniotomy, short-acting anaestheticsshould be used since the emergence and onset of anaesthesia and sedation promptly is required for such cases.
  • Remifentanyl has unique pharmacokinetics, which allow rapid onset of drug effect, precise titration to the desired effect, the ability to maintain enough effect-site concentration to suppress the stress response, and rapid recoveryfrom the drug’s effects.
  • Thus, it is ideal for awake craniotomies than other opioid analgesics.

Explanation of Other Options:

Fentanyl (Option A) : Fentanyl is not ideal for awake craniotomy because it accumulates with prolonged use, is less titratable than remifentanil, and may lead to delayed awakening, making it unsuitable when rapid recovery is needed.

Sufentanil (Option B) : Sufentanil, though potent and hemodynamically stable, is not preferred for awake craniotomy due to its tendency to accumulate during infusions and cause delayed emergence, limiting its use in procedures requiring intraoperative wakefulness.

Morphine (Option D): Morphine is a poor choice for awake craniotomy because of its slow onset, prolonged duration, active metabolites, and lack of titratability, all of which contribute to delayed awakening and reduced suitability for neurosurgical procedures that require patient interaction.

questions.text:
Regarding patient-controlled analgesia, mark the following statements true or false.
1. Allows patients to self-titrate their dosing to optimise their pain management
2. Involves a programmable electric pump to deliver a medication upon patient demand
3. A prescribed dose is delivered
4. Leads to decreased health care provider workload, increased patient satisfaction, and lower opioid consumption
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • As an alternative to intermittent bolus dosing of medication, patients may be provided with a mechanism to address their analgesic requirements, termed patient-controlled analgesia (PCA).This most typically involves a programmable electronic pump, which delivers a prescribed dose of medication upon patient demand.
  • The rationale of this technique is that, by using frequent, small doses of opioids, patients will have better control of their pain by keeping effect-site concentrations in the therapeutic range for a larger proportion of the time.
  • Rather than wide swings between inadequate analgesia and over-sedation, the PCA regimen is designed to allow patients to self-titrate their dosingto optimise their pain management.
  • Proposed advantages of this technique include
    • Decreased health care provider workload
    • Increased patient satisfaction
    • Lower opioid consumption
    • Safety of needing a conscious patient to self-administer a dose of opioid.

questions.text: Regarding the given method of opioid administration, find the incorrect statement.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shown is the transdermal fentanyl patch.

  • Fentanyl patches are most often used for outpatient management of chronic painand should be reserved for patients who require continuous opioid dosing but cannot use the much less expensive, but equally efficacious and long-acting oral agents.
  • Since acute post-operative painpatients usually are not tolerant to opioids, it is not ideal to treat their pain with fentanyl patches, since they can end up in respiratory depression

Fentanyl Patch

Mechanism & Use:

  • Highly lipophilic, low molecular weight → ideal for transdermal absorption. (Option D ruled out)
  • Provides continuous opioid delivery over 72 hours.
  • Forms a dermal depot, releasing the drug steadily into systemic circulation.

Clinical Indication:

  • Used for chronic pain in opioid-tolerant patients.
  • Not suitable for acute or postoperative pain due to slow onset (12–16 hrs) and delayed offset.

Pharmacokinetics:

  • Onset: 1–2 hrs detectable; peak ~20 hrs.
  • Steady-state: Achieved after 2–3 days.
  • Half-life after removal: 13–27 hrs due to continued release from skin.

Factors Affecting Absorption:

  • Patch surface area
  • Skin condition (hydration, temperature)( Option B ruled out)
  • Heat increases absorption → risk of overdose.

Risks:

  • Respiratory depression (delayed onset) (Option A ruled out)
  • Accidental overdose (especially in children or heat exposure)
  • Not easily titratable

questions.text: A 76-year-old man with a history of hypertension and cancer of the colon had a colectomy under general anaesthesia 24 hours ago. He is receiving an epidural infusion of fentanyl at the rate of 100 micrograms/h. Which of the following is least likely?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hypotension is least likely with fentanyl.

  • Epidural opioids can cause nausea, pruritus, and respiratory depression.
  • The biggest advantage of these agents over epidural administration of local anaesthetics is the hemodynamic stability, as there is no inhibition of the sympathetic system.
  • Hypotension is highly unlikely with epidural fentanyl administration.

Side Effects of Fentanyl (as an Anaesthetic Agent)

  • Respiratory Depression (Option C ruled out)
    • The most serious side effect
    • Dose-dependent; can occur even at clinical doses
    • Enhanced when combined with sedatives or in high-risk patients (elderly, obese)
  • Chest Wall Rigidity ("Wooden Chest Syndrome")
    • Seen with rapid IV boluses
    • Makes ventilation difficult
    • More common with high-potency opioids like fentanyl and sufentanil
  • Bradycardia
    • Due to vagal stimulation
    • To counteract the bradycardia caused by fentanyl, pancuronium is administered, which acts on the Central vagal nuclei
  • Nausea and Vomiting (Option D ruled out)
    • Common postoperative side effects
    • Related to the stimulation of the chemoreceptor trigger zone
  • Pruritus (Itching) (Option A ruled out)
    • Especially with neuraxial administration (e.g., epidural or spinal)
    • Histamine release is minimal compared to morphine, but can still occur
  • Constipation and Urinary Retention
    • More relevant with postoperative or prolonged use
    • Due to opioid-induced decreased GI motility and bladder tone
  • Sedation
    • Dose-dependent CNS depression
    • Can lead to delayed awakening or oversedation in sensitive patients
  • Tolerance and Dependence (with prolonged use)
    • Less relevant for single-dose intraoperative use, but critical in ICU or chronic pain

questions.text: The following opioids are available for intraspinal injection except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Remifentanil is not available for intraspinal injection

  • Remifentanilis formulated in combination with glycine
  • Glycine acts as an inhibitory neurotransmitterin the spinal dorsal horn that causes a reversible motor weakness when it is injected intrathecally
  • For this reason, remifentanil is not approved for spinal or epidural use
  • Remifentanyl ishydrolysed by plasma and tissue esterase. The pharmacokinetics and the pharmacodynamics of remifentanil are not altered by renal dysfunction and are the agent of choice in kidney failure

Opioids suitable for intraspinal (intrathecal or epidural) injection must have:

  • Proven safety and efficacy in the neuraxial space
  • Acceptable preservative-free formulations
  • Sufficient duration of action for spinal use

Explanation of Other Options:

Alfentanil(Option B)

  • Rarely used intraspinal, but has been studied
  • Short-acting like fentanyl, but less lipid soluble
  • Not commonly used intrathecall,y but has been evaluated
  • Still less appropriate than fentanyl or sufentanil

Sufentanil (Option C)

  • Used for intrathecal/epidural analgesia
  • Highly lipid-soluble, potent
  • Commonly used for labor analgesia and C-section
  • Faster onset and longer duration than fentanyl in the neuraxial space

Fentanyl (Option D)

  • Widely used intrathecally
  • One of the most common opioids for epidural and spinal anesthesia
  • Used for labor analgesia, C-section, and postoperative pain

questions.text: A patient undergoing general anaesthesia receives an opioid for analgesia. You are monitoring for hemodynamic changes, particularly changes in heart rate. Which of the following causes an increase in heart rate?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In general, opioids have few direct effects on the heart
  • Meperidine tends to increase heart rate(it is structurally similar to atropine and was originally synthesised as an atropine replacement)
  • It has structural similarity to atropine, which confers anticholinergic effects.
  • Also associated with histamine release, which may further stimulate reflex tachycardia.
  • Whereas larger doses of Morphine, Fentanyl, Sufentanil, Remifentanil, and Alfentanil are associated with a vagus nerve-mediated bradycardia(Option A, B & C ruled out)

questions.text: A postoperative patient receiving morphine for pain develops opioid-induced constipation. The team decides to administer a medication that antagonises opioid effects peripherally without reversing analgesia. Which of the following opioids or opioid-related drugs has predominant peripheral action?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Methyl naltrexone is a peripheral mu opioid receptor antagonist.
  • It is a quaternary ammonium compound and hence cannot cross the blood-brain barrier.
  • Thus, it can reverse the effectsof opioids mediated by peripheral opioid receptors, since it cannot cross the blood-brain barrier, it does not affect the opioid effects mediated by opioid receptors in the CNS, such as analgesia.
  • It was introduced in the treatment of opioid induced constipationrefractory to other measures.
  • Alvimopanis a similar acting peripheral mu opioid receptor antagonist.

Explanation of Other Options:

Naltrexone (Option A): A long-acting opioid antagonist, used centrally and peripherally. Crosses the blood-brain barrier (BBB). Used in opioid dependence and alcohol use disorder. Not selective for peripheral action, it would block central analgesia.

Nalbuphine (Option C): A mixed agonist-antagonist(Κ-agonist, Μ-antagonist). Acts centrally and is used for moderate to severe pain. Can cause sedation, respiratory depression, and dysphoria. Not limited to peripheral action.

Nalorphine (Option D): Another mixed agonist-antagonist. Central acting can reverse respiratory depression, but also causes dysphoria and hallucinations. Obsolete in modern practice due to side effects

questions.text: Clinical uses of fentanyl include all except?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Fentanyl cannot be used alone as a spinal anaesthetic.

It is used as an adjuvant to local anaesthetics (like bupivacaine) to:

  • Enhance analgesia
  • Prolong the block duration

Features:

  • It cannot block nerve conduction on its own.
  • Fentanyl is administered clinically in a wide range of doses.
  • Low doses of fentanyl: 1 to 2 mg/kg IV, are injected to provide analgesia (Option A ruled out)
  • Fentanyl: 2 to 20 mg/kg IV, may be administered as an adjuvant to inhaled anaesthetics to blunt circulatory responsesfor
    • Direct laryngoscopy for intubation of the trachea. (Option B ruled out)
    • Sudden changes in the level of surgical stimulation.
  • Fentanyl blunts the sympathetic surge associated with intubation by reducing:
    • Tachycardia
    • Hypertension
  • Large doses of fentanyl, like 50 to 150 mg/kg IV, have been used alone to produce surgical anaesthesia. (Option C ruled out)
  • In cardiac anaesthesia, high-dose fentanyl is often used for induction due to its cardiostability.
  • Analgesia produced by neuraxial opioids, in contrast to regional anaesthesia with local anaesthetics, is not associated with sympathectomy, sensory block, or motor weakness

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication to the use of Morphine?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Morphine is the opioid of choice for acute coronary eventslike myocardial infarction to relieve anxiety and chest pain (Option D)
  • Morphine releases histamine, which can cause bronchoconstrictionand vasodilation. Hence, it can precipitate attacks of asthma (Option B ruled out)
  • Morphine is metabolised to morphine 6-glucuronide, which can accumulate in renal failure, receiving repeated doses of morphine, leading to prolongation of respiratory depression (Option A ruled out)
  • Morphine alters the pulmonary function by decreasing the respiratory rate, minute volume, and tidal volume. It also suppresses the ventilator responses in response to hypoxia (through action on carotid and aortic body chemo sensors) and hypercapnia (through action on the brainstem chemosensory neurons). Hence, it is not safe in patients with compromised respiratory function like Cor pulmonale, emphysema, kyphoscoliosis, severe obesity(Option C rule out)
  • Other contraindications:
    • Hypotension
    • Head injury (head injury as such is not an absolute contraindication, but here would be the greater incidence of respiratory depression and other adverse effects like miosis, vomiting makes interpretation of signs of head injury difficult and thus its use is discouraged)

questions.text: A 55-year-old patient with treatment-resistant depression is scheduled for elective hernia repair under general anaesthesia. His medication history reveals he is currently taking Phenelzine, a monoamine oxidase inhibitor (MAOI), as part of his psychiatric treatment. Which of the following opioids is to be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

As the patient is on an MAO inhibitor, all the mentioned drugs should be avoided.

  • Meperidine (and methadone) inhibits the neuronal reuptake of serotonin -> serotonergic overactivity -> Serotonin Syndrome in patients receiving monoamine oxidase inhibitors (Option A)
  • The symptom complex includes
    • Fluctuations in blood pressure
    • Hyperthermia
    • Delirium
    • Convulsions
    • Coma
    • Death
  • Thus, it is not co-administered with monoamine oxidase inhibitors or used 14 days afterthe discontinuation of monoamine oxidase inhibitors
  • Tramadol (and tapentadol) inhibits the reuptake of norepinephrine and serotonin (Option B)
  • Besides, it is epileptogenicand can cause seizures in predisposed individuals and in those taking medications like monoamine oxidase inhibitors, which can lower the seizure threshold
  • Dextromethorphanis a cough suppressant, an analogue of levorphanol. It inhibits the reuptake of serotonin and is thus not to be used in patients receiving monoamine oxidase inhibitors (Option C)
  • Other opioids like Morphine, Codeine, Oxycodone, Alfentanil, and Buprenorphine are free from such interactions

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient is admitted following a road traffic accident. He has sustained both a bone fracture of the right leg and is planned for nailing of the Tibia. He is a known asthmatic on regular use of an asthalin metered dose inhaler. You have the patient nebulised before the surgery. What are the following drugs considered safe to use in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Fentanyl is considered safe to use
  • Does NOT release histamine significantly.
  • Safer in terms of avoiding bronchospasm or airway reactivity.
  • Widely used in anaesthesia for asthmatic patients.
  • Anaesthetic agents that release histamine directly include atracurium, mivacurium, morphine, and meperidine. (Option A and C ruled out)
  • They cause histamine release, mainly cutaneous, when used in patients.
  • Beta-blockers can increase airway reactivity and may interfere with the activity of beta agonists. (Option D ruled out)
  • Hence, they are avoided in asthmatic patients.

questions.text: Remifentanil is an ideal drug for total intravenous anaesthesia. This is because of the property:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Due to its ester linkages, remifentanil is susceptible to hydrolysis by blood and tissue nonspecific esterases, resulting in rapid metabolism. This allows rapid termination of its effect and referral from anaesthesia.

  • Highly lipid soluble.
  • Pharmacokinetics are uninfluenced by liver and renal failure.
  • It is not a substrate for hydrolysis by pseudocholinesterase
  • Context-sensitive half-time is around 4 minutes and is independent of the duration of infusion.

Explanation of Other Options:

Highly lipid soluble (Option A): Remifentanil is not highly lipid soluble; in fact, high lipid solubility in other opioids leads to accumulation in fat stores and delayed recovery, which is undesirable for TIVA.

Liver metabolism (Option B): Remifentanil is not metabolized by the liver, and reliance on hepatic metabolism would make its clearance variable and dependent on liver function, reducing its predictability and safety in TIVA.

Kidney metabolism (Option C): Remifentanil is not cleared by the kidneys, and drugs that rely on renal metabolism can accumulate in patients with kidney dysfunction, making them less suitable for precise and rapid recovery as required in TIVA.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia is given morphine intraoperatively for analgesia. In the PACU, she develops nausea and vomiting. You suspect this is due to opioid administration. Which of the following is not a known mechanism by which opioids cause postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV)?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

CTZ stimulation, decreased gastric intestinal motility, and Prolonged gastric emptying are the mechanisms for postoperative nausea and vomiting, except decreased sphincter tone.

  • Opioids can reduce LES tone, which may:
    • Lead to gastroesophageal reflux (GERD)
    • Increase risk of aspiration, especially under anaesthesia
  • However, this is not a primary emetogenic mechanism.
  • LES tone has more to do with regurgitation or acid reflux than triggering the vomiting reflex.

Mechanism of PONV

Chemoreceptor Trigger Zone (CTZ) Stimulation (Option A):

  • Mechanism: Opioids stimulate the μ-receptors in the CTZ, located in the area postrema of the medulla (outside the blood-brain barrier).
  • This activation directly triggers the vomiting centre in the medulla.
  • Key point: This is a primary and well-established mechanism for opioid-induced nausea/vomiting.

Decreased Gastrointestinal (GI) Motility (Option B):

  • Opioids bind to μ-opioid receptors in the enteric nervous system, causing:
    • Reduced peristalsis
    • Increased segmental contractions
    • Distention of the gut
  • This leads to vagal stimulation, which feeds back to the vomiting centre.
  • Contributes both to nausea and constipation.

Prolonged Gastric Emptying(Option C):

  • Opioids delay gastric emptying, leading to gastric stasis.
  • This can increase the sensation of fullness, distention, and nausea.
  • Particularly important postoperatively or in opioid-naive patients.

questions.text: A 35-year-old hypothyroid male underwent ACL arthroscopic repair of the right knee under general anaesthesia. He had a delayed recovery after surgery and was administered Naloxone. He was reversed and extubated. In the recovery, the patient developed hypoventilation. This may be attributed to:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Following naloxone administration, patients should be observed closely for recurrence of opioid-induced respiratory depression (“renarcotization”), as naloxone has a shorter duration of action than many opioids.

Renarcotization refers to the recurrence of opioid-induced respiratory depression after an initial reversal with naloxone, due to:

  • Shorter half-life of naloxone (~30–90 minutes)
  • Longer duration of action of opioids like morphine or fentanyl
  • Once naloxone wears off, the residual opioid rebinds to receptors, causing hypoventilation or sedation

This is especially common in patients who received long-acting or high-dose opioids intraoperatively.

Explanation of Other Options:

Inadequate recovery (Option A): Could cause hypoventilation, but this patient was initially reversed and extubated successfully.

Residual blockade (Option B): Refers to neuromuscular blockade (e.g., from rocuronium or vecuronium). Would result in muscle weakness, but not usually after confirmed reversal/extubation unless TOF monitoring showed residual blockade.

Opioid-related respiratory depression (Option C): This was initially treated with naloxone. The delayed recurrence implies renarcotization, not a failure of the initial reversal.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male underwent ACL reconstruction of the left knee under general anaesthesia and adductor canal block. After the surgery, the Inhalational agents were stopped, and reversal was given with Neostigmine (with glycopyrrolate). He did not regain consciousness or make spontaneous efforts to breathe. Given that he received a high dose of Morphine for premedication, the next line of management will include the following
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Intravenous naloxone (in 80μg increments in adults)  is the next line of management.

  • When the patient fails to regain consciousness within an expected period after general anaesthesia, the most frequent cause is residual drug effect.
  • Delayed emergence may occur as a result of absolute or relative drug overdose.
  • The effects of preoperative sleep deprivation or drug ingestion (alcohol, sedatives) can be additive to those of anaesthetic agents in producing prolonged emergence.
  • Intravenous naloxone and flumazenil will readily reverse the effects of an opioid and benzodiazepine, respectively. Intravenous physostigmine may partially reverse the effect of other agents.

Intravenous Naloxone

  • Opioid antagonist that reverses the effects of opioids, especially respiratory depression and CNS depression.
  • Acts rapidly by displacing opioids from μ-receptors.
  • Indicated when a patient has:
    • Decreased consciousness
    • Hypoventilation or apnea
    • Known/suspected opioid overdose

Explanation of Other Options:

Flumazenil (Option B): Flumazenil is a benzodiazepine antagonist that reverses the effects of drugs like midazolam and diazepam but has no effect on opioids, making it ineffective if opioids are the primary cause of delayed awakening.

Physostigmine (Option C): Physostigmine is a reversible cholinesterase inhibitor that crosses the blood–brain barrier and is sometimes used for central anticholinergic syndrome, but it is not effective in opioid-induced sedation or apnea and carries risks such as seizures and bradycardia.

Ondansetron (Option D): Ondansetron is a 5-HT3 receptor antagonist used to treat nausea and vomiting, with no role in reversing opioid effects or managing delayed awakening.
